intro: Achillea umbellata, commonly known as the common yarrow, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its flat, clustered flower heads that resemble umbels. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–90 cm and features finely divided, fern-like leaves. Its flowers are usually white or pale yellow, and it blooms from late spring to early autumn. Achillea umbellata is often found in meadows, roadsides, and disturbed soils, and it has been used historically for its medicinal properties.
